deliver it or careless actions like these can turn any business into a risky business the stakes are high personal reputations careers company profits and imprison people like art boom took big risks and lost

I think the case study you've just seen gives you a good idea of how dangerous price-fixing is and how easy it is for seemingly innocent conversations to in fact be serious violations of the law that's why it's so important that you never discuss any business matters with any of our competitors don't collaborate with them on any selling issues and don't send messages to them through middlemen like one of our direct accounts of course that means

no joint merchandising are other selling presentations to customers and that also means you shouldn't ever discuss any of your account activities with any of our competitors even bragging about your accomplishments and what you did in a specific store or with a particular chain can potentially cause serious problems it's sometimes easy to get caught off guard at trade shows it's easy to forget that you're there to talk with our customers not are

predators and simple questions like how's business going might seem Innocent but they can open a can of antitrust worms they are two specific areas I'd like to briefly discuss collecting competitive information and the language you use to describe your activities the law says that you shouldn't discuss competitive activities with your competitors but there is nothing wrong with getting competitive information from third parties such as

wholesalers and retailers if you get pricing information from or provide pricing information to a competing sales rep you've put yourself in a difficult situation because you've created the appearance of collusion even if the two of you didn't say a word to each other on the other hand if a wholesaler provides you with information about our competitors prices payments promotions or whatever great send the information to Winston-Salem

mmm we may be able to use that information to compete more effectively against the other tobacco companies but if you're collecting competitive information it is very important that you identify the source telling Who provided it for example if you get a copy of a competitor's merchandising contract on the document itself jot down the name of the customer Who provided it or if you write up information on a competitors program to be

it to Winston-Salem also note the source of your information otherwise the presence of that kind of document in our files could imply to an antitrust investigator or opposing lawyer that it was obtained pursuant to an improper arrangement with a competitor when you're talking or writing about your sales activities it's a good idea to file a several simple guidelines in your choice of words first when discussing a

writing about competition and prices avoid giving the false impression that the company is not competing vigorously or that our prices are based on anything other than our own business judgment or that its public statements are signals to competitors second avoid using words that may falsely imply that the company is pursuing a course of action as a matter of Industry agreement or industry policy rather than as a

out of our own self-interest and finally don't use guilt complex words such as please destroy after reading careful language will not avoid or hide any trust violations when the conduct involved is illegal but you don't want to make lawful conduct appear suspect because of a poor choice of words in litigation there are no secrets and essentially all of our files would be produced to

opposing lawyers you can be sure they will argue that your carelessly or inaccurately written memo properly described our purpose in 10th or conduct most of what you've heard so far concerns understandings with our competitors but you must remember that anti-competitive activity doesn't just concern our competitors it also relates to our dealings with customers and I want to point out several things in this area too

our customers have the right to determine their own selling prices and their other business activities while we can discuss these matters with them and suggest what we think they ought to do we must make it clear that the final decision is theirs and we can't attempt to intimidate or coerce them into following our recommendations we have the right to unilaterally accept or reject anyone who applies to become a direct account but that decision

Asian can't be based on an understanding between us in any of the applicants competitors or as potential competitors or between us and our competitors so under no circumstance should you discuss possible action on applications for direct list with people outside the company the best thing to do is say nothing

we should also avoid appearing to steer business to a particular distributor of favoring one distributor over another if a retailer asked where he should buy his cigarettes give him a list of all Distributors that service the area if you're asked where they can buy at a lower price tell them to shop around but don't refer them to a particular distributor and don't disparage a Distributors business or financial condition and conversations

retail customers or with other distributors in fact you just shouldn't discuss a customer's business with any of his competitors in general we should treat competing customers in a fair and Equitable manner in terms of how we price our products and make available premiums coupons and the like the basic objective is to avoid giving One customer and advantage over those who are trying to compete with him while they are

some exceptions generally in selling similar products we need to avoid price discriminations that enable One customer to take business away from his competitor and selling tools like premiums and coupons should generally be available on a proportionate basis for those accounts that are competing with one another one of the principal exceptions to these general rules is that a price difference or disproportionate treatment with premiums or coupons

be justified if they're necessary for us to be equal with an offer by one of our competitors but a meeting competition price or coupon is not justified if it was intended to beat what you believe our competitor has put or is likely to put on the table meeting competition offers must be authorized by the home office in Winston-Salem authorization will be communicated down to the appropriate level in the field along with any necessary instructions

Azure requirements I hope you found this film informative if you have any questions ask your management for guidance don't act first and then ask questions later Sales Management will contact me or one of the other lawyers in the department if they need assistance for your further guidance we are redistributing the company's updated guide for compliance with the antitrust laws it will be sent to you soon thank you
